Message.Title: Take it From a Previous BAC Bear, BAC IS HEADED HIGHER!!!
Message.Msg: I was BAC's biggest critic...I was able to successfully short BAC from thew 14 level to the 6 dollar level from 2011 to 2012...I was fortunate enough to make big gains; however, I was short because BAC had serious fundamental issues. Since 2012, particularly when BAC, among other banks, passed what was expected to be a difficult series of stress tests, I got long BAC...Particularly, I began to get long BAC at the 8.40 level...Though I was not originally sold on the BAC story, I had to admit that they [BAC] continued to quietly take away the "Bear Case." My biggest sticking point were the suits related to the MBSs; however, if you have noticed, this issue has been quietly going away. Last, is the latest settlement suit concerning the 8.5 billion dollar settlement, which I believe, will turn out favorably for BAC. Once this news hits, I see BAC running to the $20 level. Take it from a previous bear, once BAC gets momentum, you do not want to be on the wrong side of this stock's upward movement.

Message.Title: Chegg selects Banks IPO.
Message.Msg: Textbook rental company Chegg has selected two banks to lead an initial public offering, according to three sources familiar with the matter. The Santa Clara, California-based company has picked JPMorgan Chase & Co (JPM.N) and Bank of America Corp (BAC.N), the sources said. The offering could raise $200 million, one of the sources said. JPMorgan and Bank of America declined to comment. Chegg could not be reached for comment. Launched nationally in 2007, Chegg has raised more than $200 million in venture funding and debt. Its investors include Insight Venture Partners, Foundation Capital, Gabriel Venture Partners and Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. The company plants a tree for every textbook it rents or sells and has planted more than 5 million trees to date, according to its website

Message.Title: HUGE Dividend Being Paid to Shareholders at Today's Close
Message.Msg: Imagine a tech stock with forecasted earnings growth of 191% that just raised its quarterly cash dividend by 100% and now has a HUGE dividend yield of 6%! Only one stock like this exists today and their BIG quarterly cash dividend is being paid to those who own the stock at TODAY's close! Copy and Pasted from the NASDAQ's Web Site: Concurrent Computer Corporation ( CCUR ) will begin trading ex-dividend on June 13, 2013. A cash dividend payment of $0.12 per share is scheduled to be paid on June 28, 2013. Shareholders who purchased CCUR stock prior to the ex-dividend date are eligible for the cash dividend payment. This represents an 100% increase over the prior quarter. At the current stock price of $8.04, the dividend yield is 5.97%. The previous trading day's last sale of CCUR was $8.04, representing a -4.85% decrease from the 52 week high of $8.45 and a 116.71% increase over the 52 week low of $3.71. CCUR is a part of the Technology sector, which includes companies such as Apple Inc. ( AAPL ) and International Business Machines Corporation ( IBM ). CCUR's current earnings per share, an indicator of a company's profitability, is $.25. Zacks Investment Research reports CCUR's forecasted earnings growth in 2013 as 191.18%, compared to an industry average of 3.7%. For more information on the declaration, record and payment dates, visit the CCUR Dividend History page.

Message.Title: BAC good buy at 13 - by mid-july could be over 14 and by sept-oct over 18
Message.Msg: The $8.5 bi settlement should be approved by early July which will give at least a 10% boost to stock price. The investors took risk when they invested in MBS so the judge would say the settlement is fair - the complainers are just trying to milk more money based on technical reasons. Lower deliquencies, bigger loan portfolio, and strong investment banking will show that BAC has a huge profit potential. By Sept-Oct should easily move up to $18 range.

Message.Title: More democrap carbon tax hocus pocus
Message.Msg: For example, the administration’s vehicle fuel-efficiency standards would cost industry $350 billion over the next 40 years, while benefits in energy security, less congestion and lower pollution totaled $278 billion, according to a regulatory analysis using the prior carbon cost estimates cited in a paper by administration economists. It’s only by including the $177 billion in benefits from less carbon dioxide that the rules provide a net benefit to the country, according to the paper by Michael Greenstone, now an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Message.Title: ROFLMFO, inflation at historic lows due to financial services and insurance.
Message.Msg: You remember not long ago about some redefinitions? Anyone think those have had an impact? I sincerely don't know and quite frankly I don't give a heck. is the gov printing EBT cards for day traders ? The obligations are becoming more and more things like food and while medical is citing as dropping in costs, how can that be sustained? This deflation is largely just collapsing bubbles Reduced insurance rates can be a sign that losses are down, a good tihng, except you keep reading about wheather related losses. So how is insurance down? Car insurance? Gov printing the difference? Insurance can not really be in short supply. Once they let 29 year old high school drop outs become doctors, medical inflation will be well under control ROFLMFO. And I'm not siding with AMA or really criticizing Booz, just pointing to the extreme opposite occuring of what everyone tried to create.. The rise of the recreational drug economy is likely to come along with a sex industry, again nothing inherently wrong with that if that is what you wanted. Prositution at Hillaries state department, this is hilariious if true. Tampon praising death spiral is doing quite well. Luckily gas prices have been fairly stable and China is not consuming everything they produce, they are still willing to work for our promises.
